abstract.text: A container for the color or texture of one of a material’s visual properties.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A material has several visual properties that together determine its appearance under lighting and shading. SceneKit renders each pixel in the scene by combining the information from material properties with the locations, intensities, and colors of lights.

A material property’s contents can be either a color, which provides a uniform effect across the surface of a material, or a texture, which SceneKit maps across the surface of a material using texture coordinates provided by the geometry object the material is attached to. A texture, in turn, can come from any of several sources, such as an image object, a URL to an image file, a specially formatted image or set of images for use as a cube map, or even animated content provided by Core Animation, SpriteKit, or AVFoundation—for the full set of options, see the
property.

Typically, you associate texture images with materials when creating 3D assets with third-party authoring tools, and the scene files containing those assets reference external image files. For best results when shipping assets in your app bundle, place scene files in a folder with the
extension, and place image files referenced as textures from those scenes in an Asset Catalog.

Xcode then optimizes the scene and texture resources for best performance on each target device, and prepares your texture resources for delivery features such as App Thinning and On-Demand Resources.
SceneKit uses the material property’s
object in different ways for each visual property of a material. For example:
When you provide a color for the

property, it determines the material’s base color—geometries using the material appear shaded in gradations of this color when illuminated by white light. If you instead provide an image, SceneKit maps the image across the geometry’s surface instead of shading with a uniform base color.
When you provide a color for the

property, it affects the color of light reflected directly toward the viewer from the surface of a geometry using the material. If you instead provide a grayscale image, it determines the tendency of the material to reflect light directly toward the viewer—lighter pixels in the image make those areas of the material appear more shiny, and darker pixels make the material appear more matte.
The

property specifies the orientation of a surface at each point. Materials are uniformly smooth by default, so specifying a color for this property has no useful effect. Instead, you can specify an image for this property that describes the contours of the surface. SceneKit uses this image (called a normal map) in lighting, creating the illusion of a complex, bumpy surface without increasing the complexity of the geometry.
For more details on each visual property and the ways their contents affect a material’s appearance, see
SceneKit also uses
objects elsewhere:
To provide content to be rendered behind a scene, in the
property of an
object,
To affect the color and shape of illumination from a light source, in the
property of an
object.
To bind texture samplers to custom GLSL shader source code snippets, in classes conforming to the
protocol.

abstract.text: Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
The common interface for attaching animations to nodes, geometries, materials, and other SceneKit objects.
A set of camera attributes that can be attached to a node to provide a point of view for displaying the scene.
Texture filtering modes, used by the
, and
properties.
A light source that can be attached to a node to illuminate the scene.
An image or other visual content affecting the shape and color of a light’s illuminated area.
A set of shading attributes that define the appearance of a geometry’s surface when rendered.
An object that manages the material’s diffuse response to lighting.
An object that defines the nominal orientation of the surface at each point for use in lighting.
An object that manages the material’s specular response to lighting.
A container for the color or texture of one of a material’s visual properties.
A color used to fill in areas of a material’s surface not covered by the material property’s image contents.
The visual contents of the material property—a color, image, or source of animated content. Animatable.
The transformation applied to the material property’s visual contents. Animatable.
Creates a new material property object with the specified contents.
A number between
and
that modulates the effect of the material property. Animatable.
Texture filtering for rendering the material property’s image contents at a size larger than that of the original image.
The source of texture coordinates for mapping the material property’s image contents.
The amount of anisotropic texture filtering to be used when rendering the material property’s image contents.
Texture filtering for rendering the material property’s image contents at a size smaller than that of the original image.
Texture filtering for using mipmaps to render the material property’s image contents at a size smaller than that of the original image.
The wrapping behavior for the S texture coordinate.
The wrapping behavior for the T texture coordinate.
A container for the node hierarchy and global properties that together form a displayable 3D scene.
A background to be rendered before the rest of the scene.
Methods for customizing SceneKit’s rendering of geometry and materials using Metal or OpenGL shader programs.
Modes to apply to texture wrapping, used by the
and
properties.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
